title: Before 2018, will there be a lethal attack on a US military vessel in the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden, Persian Gulf, or Gulf of Oman?
preds: The payoff for attacking at sea is low: can't overwhelm a Navy ship for a morale-boosting raid, and the trip back from international waters is likely to be dogged by drones.
Confidence in US Navy's point defense availabilities, and doubt about the capabilities and commitment of enemies.
Doubling the curve simply because they (Iranians) tend to mis-behave when North Korea pulls a stunt like they did yesterday.
More likely the US military vessel will run into something
Its come to my attention that the Navy hasn't a single carrier group in the Med or the Gulf, lowering the chances since the 20-25 vessels in the gulf that accompany AC Groups are Korea bound.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Small possibility of a successful terrorist attack but running out of time.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Decreasing for passage of time.  Even though Trump just refused to re-certify Iranian compliance with JCPOA, the easiest path for Iran is to speak aggressively but wait until at least the 60-day period for the US congress to take action is over ( https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/15/briefing/mogadishu-iran-north-korea.html ).
Even if an attack were to occur, I do not believe it would become lethal.
Kims weapons even iran or russia or china
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Presumably it won't count if the event involves yet another US ship ramming someone else....

In the incident (below) when a US plane had to avoid an Iranian drone, if the US plane had not been able to avoid hitting the drone and the collision had caused the plane to crash, would the drone have been considered to be attacking the plane?
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-40871025
I assume it would be a matter of debate, if it was considered that the drone was being deliberately flown into the plane it would be an attack. If it was considered that the drone was just being flown it a stupid place I assume it would not be considered an attack. 
I would expect that both the US and Iran would both want to put such incidents down to a stupid action (by the other side) rather than a deliberate attack. So I am sticking to my zero forecast.

Long term fatal attacks/year is low.  (supports a low prob) 
No recent fatalities have occurred  (24 interactions in 2015, 35 interactions in 2016 and <10 in 2017) (supports low prob) 
Sea lanes are patrolled by multinational consortium, reducing likelihood of attack on US military vessel --unless specifically targeted (supports low prob).

nobodys looking, congress is about to light it up with strong arming european energy contracts and some countries are really pissed with u.s. policy favoring deals with the saudis.  its a small area with very important naval passage.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-us-gulf-tension-idUSKBN1AE0DN
The more fooling around there is, the better the chance of a fatal error.  Still, all the state players are being pretty careful, so the only remotely likely chance is an attack by a nonstate group.  Maybe the New York Mets?
Iran says new tensions between Revolutionary Guards and U.S. Navy

Three incidents have occurred in the last 9 months or so that could have progressed to a lethal attack. (The missiles from Yemen and two approaches by Iranian naval vessels that were provocative.) However making a provocative approach is a long way short of an attack.  The fact that missiles were fired at the US Navy, and the fact that in the latest incident gun fire was used by the US as a deterrent shows that the US Navy is acting as if it believes its ships could be targets and is ready to deal with anything that looks like an attack. An attack would be far more likely to succeed in circumstances where a Navel vessel assumes that any nearby boat presents no risk. (I have sailed close to Naval ships without causing any alarm, presumably because my boat did not look as if it presented any risk.)   
The question specifically refers to "an attack", which seems to rule out an accidental death caused by a provocative action that went wrong. 
Therefore I am sticking to my forecast.

Not familiar with this topic. GJP seems to very much so think not, but I'm still a tad worried with all the warning missiles having been fired our way recently. That's why I'm going with 3% rather than 0,1, or 2%

Oh, oh... A U.S. Navy ship fired warning shots toward an Iranian vessel near the northern Arabian Gulf on Tuesday after the vessel came within 150 yards (137 meters), a U.S. official told Reuters.  http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-iran-military-idUSKBN1AA1P3
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Highly unlikely, but 15% chance in the event Iran arms Houthi rebels with sophisticated anti-ship missiles.
Unlikely, but possible. Don't think there will be a lethal attack, but anticipate similar hostile incidents to those recently.

It seems less likely to happen now than it has for some time. The most likely attackers would be Iran or more likely a terrorist/militia group funded by Iran, but (in my opinion)  the current instability of region makes this less likely now. There are a number of other places (e.g. around Mosul or Raqqa) where Iran or its surrogates could engineer an incident against the USA. So Iran probably does not want another incident to deal with.
There is another (remote) possibility that as IS is driven out of Syria and Iraq it could stage an attack elsewhere and perhaps try a suicide boat bomb (e.g. load a fishing boat with explosive and ram it into a US military vessel)
It's still a very real, albeit very unlikely risk. However, the community also didn't think North Korea would launch an ICBM (myself included) so I'm wary to rule this out completely.

There is some risk that a vessel might be attacked in port during the period, but non Russian naval powers are unlikely to be able to successfully attack a USA ship, while the likelihood of conflict with Russian is very low over the timeframe indicated
Dateline June 20, 2017 SitRep From: Foreign Policy <fp@foreignpolicy.com>

Doesn't have to be a state actor, or even necessarily related to anything else.  Doesn't have to be an actual battle:  Remember the Cole and before that the Stark.  Enough folks are behaving oddly in that part of the world that I'm bumping up, but only from 1 to 4 for the moment.

http://foreignpolicy.com/2017/06/16/white-house-officials-push-for-widening-war-in-syria-over-pentagon-objections/
@rlfmgy @rene @vegasman2000 @Dsarin Do you think this might warrant increasing likelihood? Where's my fallout shelter!
If U.S. action in Syria continues, this question may bear watching.
Unless the situation with Qatar  is resolved quickly this could happen by accident.
http://en.alalam.ir/news/1983478 Yemeni Navy launched an anti-ship missile towards the Saudi military naval transport that was supposedly carrying weapons and ammo.
Never stay never. The probability is close to zero given the fierce response expected from US forces.
An attack won't succeed without surprise, which has been lost
Moving up by 2% due to tensions in Qatar.
Tendenz zu bewussten Anschlag welche allerdings nicht vom offensichtlichen Feind kommen wird eventuell von der Waffenindustrie da diese  ein starker Profiteur von Trumps daraufolgende Politik wÃ¤re.

There have been three known attacks in the last 50 years that have been deadly: USS Cole in 2000, USS Stark in 1987, USS Pueblo in  1968.
That translates to ~3 lethal attacks over 50 years or 6% chance per year.  
We are halfway through the year, so I am going with 3%.
The threat level is very high and the US Military is taking extraordinary steps to ensure security.  US Military vessels are well defended.  It is likely that US enemies will seek softer targets.
Down a point to follow the crowd; however unlikely this is, it can't be discounted, since the scenario that closes this question as a "Yes" almost certainly will be a black swan.
Recent iranian elections suggest no. But President Trump may create the conditions for it to happen regardless. Currently improbable.

I really do not think that a U.S. fatality in this operational area is likely. I see only a few situations where attacks or confrontations are posible, however I do not see any of these resulting in a U.S. casualty.

Lethal attacks on US naval vessels during "peacetime" are rare. Just a quick wikipedia search seems like they occur roughly once every 25 years. That sets the baseline for an attack at 4% globally. Now, let's assume that only a quarter of the US Navy's ships are normally located in the waters in question. We're looking at a baseline of 1% here. Now, the conflicts in the area do slightly increase the probability of a lethal attack taking place. As the description stated, there have been several attempts in the past few months. However, coming from non-state actors, the chances of these successfully striking a US vessel seem slim.

It does happen that US military navy vessels are the target of attacks, deliberate or in error. A rather complete list can be found here: https://www.historyguy.com/attacks_on_us_naval_ships.htm
In October 2016, there were 3 attempts to attack the USS Mason. The ship itself was not hit, but countermeasures had to be used. Likely countries like Iran, or for all that matters Saudi Arabia, still realize that the power of the American military is more than sufficient to retaliate hard. This leaves as possible attackers some terrorist, rebels or pirates who do not really care about retaliation, or an attack/hit in error. The area defined is littered badly with underwater mines, which make a hit not unlikely (20%?), however, this does not immediately have to be a lethal hit. Since the time frame , the next 7 months, is rather short I believe the likelihood to be low, but not impossible.

There hasn't been a lethal attack on a US military vessel for many, many years around the world. There's no reason to think there's anything special about Houthi rebels, who lack any strong power outside of Yemen. Even ISIS, which probably has more means, has not attacked a US military vessel in the region. Furthermore, similar incidents have not occurred in the months since the attack. Lastly, there are no good incentives for the rebels to trigger US military retaliation given their struggle against the current government in Yemen. If the rebels were truly interested in attacking US vessels, why didn't they continue to fire missiles after the incident?
A US naval vessel is a attractive target for The Houthis and the Iranis.   Any confrontation would be a publicity coup, regardless of how minor.
There hasn't been one in a long time, and it seems unlikely there would be one soon based on current geopolitics and military capabilities, if there was one I don't think it would be lethal.
Although Houthi rebels may try to hit a US military vessel, chances are small they will actually hit it and be lethal. US Navy will most probably intercept any missile before it hits a ship.
Houthi's have the capability and so could Al Qaeda.  Other option is Trump forces Iran to do so to have a casus belli or something likewise.

There is nothing to be gained from an attack of this nature.
No State desires war with the United States, and no non-State actors have the capability to sink a Naval vessel.
So any attack would be superficial and only embolden U.S. retaliation.
There is always the possibility, but the odds of the attack coming directly from a nation state is very low at this moment in time.

Over the past decade only one ship has been sunk because of conflict, a South Korean ship. Tension in the region remains high but any military attack has huge risks including retaliation and/or economic sanctions.

Now president Trump is playing the power muscle all around the globe, increasing the military presence all around. This purely mathematically increases the chance of incidents. Since the question allows for non-governmental issued damage (rebels, pirates) which are known to be rather active in that area, I seen another increase in chance.
They know the repercussions would be too great and result in more fatalities on the opposing side. A non-lethal attack is much more likely.

The US Navy is one of the most well equipped and trained in the world - despite growing incursions/violations by foreign attackers, the likelihood of an attack may rise but a fatality is relatively small.

As I see it there are only two possibilities for a lethal attack, terrorism and Iran. It's possible the Houthi's or Al Queda may get lucky with an attack but its been 17 years  since a terrorist actually killed anyone on a US military vessel. And I don't see Iran launching lethal attacks anytime soon considering their president is not looking for a fight.
I'm assuming wounds that cause a death not on the battlefield count towards this.
The most likely antagonists are still studying Trump and are not ready to engage him at that level in 2017.

It would be a big mistake for Iran to initiate any action that would lead to a US fatality and it is unlikely that the Houthi rebels have the expertise to do it. The only reason I even give this 3% is that I wonder how much control Rouhani has over Iran's military?
Starting low, but not sure why.  Probably regret it....

The most significant naval threat to the US in the above bodies of water is Iran.  Besides the USS Cole in 2000, terrorist organizations have stuck to land.  The Iranian Navy is mostly a large number of small missile ships.  Military experts refer to the Iranian Naval strategy as  "the swarm".  If Iran decided to attack any US Naval based military vessel, the US has a number of plans, including using the A-10 Warthog plane, which was designed as an air to land attack vessel.  I predict, with certainty, no lethal attacks will take place on a US military vessel in the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden, Persian Gulf, or Gulf of Oman.

Keeping low for the moment, but I note that an adversary of the U.S. does not have to initiate the confrontation that leads to the lethal attack. In other words, an Iranian retaliation for a U.S. strike could close the question as a "Yes."

With 7 months left in the period, I think the likelihood is low. While the IRGC likes to keep things interesting with the USN, both sides recognize that a provocation resulting in use of force would have negative results. This isn't to say that the IRGC will stop harassing USN vessels, but that it is something they consider when they approach USN vessels. Should the IRGC actually decide to provoke the USN, it's still a low likelihood of a lethal attack, as USN vessels are sufficiently protected from small arms, and the use of larger weapons like missiles or rockets begins to get into the tactics and doctrine of the USN. I'm confident that, with the exception of a few rare scenarios, attacks would probably not be lethal (assuming lethal means the death of at least one US sailor).
